HelpDataItem.name: L2 Tower Lua Scripts Help
Build in - Lua 5.1
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 The standard Lua libraries provide useful functions that are implemented directly through the C API. Some of these functions provide essential services to the language (e.g., type and getmetatable); others provide access to "outside" services (e.g., I/O); and others could be implemented in Lua itself, but are quite useful or have critical performance requirements that deserve an implementation in C (e.g., table.sort).\par \par All libraries are implemented through the official C API and are provided as separate C modules. Currently, Lua has the following standard libraries:\par \par basic library, which includes the coroutine sub-library;\par package library;\par string manipulation;\par table manipulation;\par mathematical functions (sin, log, etc.);\par input and output;\par operating system facilities;\par debug facilities.\par Except for the basic and package libraries, each library provides all its functions as fields of a global table or as methods of its objects.\par \par To have access to these libraries, the C host program should call the luaL_openlibs function, which opens all standard libraries. Alternatively, it can open them individually by calling luaopen_base (for the basic library), luaopen_package (for the package library), luaopen_string (for the string library), luaopen_table (for the table library), luaopen_math (for the mathematical library), luaopen_io (for the I/O library), luaopen_os (for the Operating System library), and luaopen_debug (for the debug library). These functions are declared in lualib.h and should not be called directly: you must call them like any other Lua C function, e.g., by using lua_call.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: Global vars and functions
_G
_VERSION
assert (v [, message])
collectgarbage (opt [, arg])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 collectgarbage (opt [, arg])\par \par This function is a generic interface to the garbage collector. It performs different functions according to its first argument, opt:\par \par "stop": stops the garbage collector.\par "restart": restarts the garbage collector.\par "collect": performs a full garbage-collection cycle.\par "count": returns the total memory in use by Lua (in Kbytes).\par "step": performs a garbage-collection step. The step "size" is controlled by arg (larger values mean more steps) in a non-specified way. If you want to control the step size you must experimentally tune the value of arg. Returns true if the step finished a collection cycle.\par "setpause": sets arg as the new value for the pause of the collector (see \'a72.10). Returns the previous value for pause.\par "setstepmul": sets arg as the new value for the step multiplier of the collector (see \'a72.10). Returns the previous value for step.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: dofile (filename)
error (message [, level])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 error (message [, level])\par \par Terminates the last protected function called and returns message as the error message. Function error never returns.\par Usually, error adds some information about the error position at the beginning of the message. The level argument specifies how to get the error position. With level 1 (the default), the error position is where the error function was called. Level 2 points the error to where the function that called error was called; and so on. Passing a level 0 avoids the addition of error position information to the message.\par \par }

HelpDataItem.name: load (func [, chunkname])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 load (func [, chunkname])\par \par Loads a chunk using function func to get its pieces. Each call to func must return a string that concatenates with previous results. A return of an empty string, nil, or no value signals the end of the chunk.\par \par If there are no errors, returns the compiled chunk as a function; otherwise, returns nil plus the error message. The environment of the returned function is the global environment.\par \par chunkname is used as the chunk name for error messages and debug information. When absent, it defaults to "=(load)".\par }

HelpDataItem.name: loadfile ([filename])
loadstring (string [, chunkname])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 loadstring (string [, chunkname])\par \par Similar to load, but gets the chunk from the given string.\par \par To load and run a given string, use the idiom\par \par assert(loadstring(s))()\par \par When absent, chunkname defaults to the given string.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: module (name [, ···])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 module (name [, \'b7\'b7\'b7])\par \par Creates a module. If there is a table in package.loaded[name], this table is the module. Otherwise, if there is a global table t with the given name, this table is the module. Otherwise creates a new table t and sets it as the value of the global name and the value of package.loaded[name]. This function also initializes t._NAME with the given name, t._M with the module (t itself), and t._PACKAGE with the package name (the full module name minus last component; see below). Finally, module sets t as the new environment of the current function and the new value of package.loaded[name], so that require returns t.\par \par If name is a compound name (that is, one with components separated by dots), module creates (or reuses, if they already exist) tables for each component. For instance, if name is a.b.c, then module stores the module table in field c of field b of global a.\par \par This function can receive optional options after the module name, where each option is a function to be applied over the module.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: next (table [, index])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 next (table [, index])\par \par Allows a program to traverse all fields of a table. Its first argument is a table and its second argument is an index in this table. next returns the next index of the table and its associated value. When called with nil as its second argument, next returns an initial index and its associated value. When called with the last index, or with nil in an empty table, next returns nil. If the second argument is absent, then it is interpreted as nil. In particular, you can use next(t) to check whether a table is empty.\par \par The order in which the indices are enumerated is not specified, even for numeric indices. (To traverse a table in numeric order, use a numerical for or the ipairs function.)\par \par The behavior of next is undefined if, during the traversal, you assign any value to a non-existent field in the table. You may however modify existing fields. In particular, you may clear existing fields.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: pairs (t)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 pairs (t)\par \par Returns three values: the next function, the table t, and nil, so that the construction\par \par for k,v in pairs(t) do body end\par \par will iterate over all key\f1 -value pairs of table t.\par \par See function next for the caveats of modifying the table during its traversal.\f0\par }
HelpDataItem.example: for k,v in pairs(t) do body end

HelpDataItem.name: pcall (f, arg1, ···)

require (modname)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 require (modname)\par \par Loads the given module. The function starts by looking into the package.loaded table to determine whether modname is already loaded. If it is, then require returns the value stored at package.loaded[modname]. Otherwise, it tries to find a loader for the module.\par \par To find a loader, require is guided by the package.loaders array. By changing this array, we can change how require looks for a module. The following explanation is based on the default configuration for package.loaders.\par \par First require queries package.preload[modname]. If it has a value, this value (which should be a function) is the loader. Otherwise require searches for a Lua loader using the path stored in package.path. If that also fails, it searches for a C loader using the path stored in package.cpath. If that also fails, it tries an all-in-one loader (see package.loaders).\par \par Once a loader is found, require calls the loader with a single argument, modname. If the loader returns any value, require assigns the returned value to package.loaded[modname]. If the loader returns no value and has not assigned any value to package.loaded[modname], then require assigns true to this entry. In any case, require returns the final value of package.loaded[modname].\par \par If there is any error loading or running the module, or if it cannot find any loader for the module, then require signals an error.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: select (index, ···)
setfenv (f, table)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 setfenv (f, table)\par \par Sets the environment to be used by the given function. f can be a Lua function or a number that specifies the function at that stack level: Level 1 is the function calling setfenv. setfenv returns the given function.\par \par As a special case, when f is 0 setfenv changes the environment of the running thread. In this case, setfenv returns no values.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: setmetatable (table, metatable)

(You cannot change the metatable of other types from Lua, only from C.) If metatable is nil, removes the metatable of the given table. If the original metatable has a "__metatable" field, raises an error.\par \par This function returns table.\par \par }

HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 unpack (list [, i [, j]])\par \par Returns the elements from the given table. This function is equivalent to\par return list[i], list[i+1], \'b7\'b7\'b7, list[j]\par except that the above code can be written only for a fixed number of elements. By default, i is 1 and j is the length of the list, as defined by the length operator (see \'a72.5.5).\par }

HelpDataItem.name: xpcall (f, err)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 xpcall (f, err)\par \par This function is similar to pcall, except that you can set a new error handler.\par \par xpcall calls function f in protected mode, using err as the error handler. Any error inside f is not propagated; instead, xpcall catches the error, calls the err function with the original error object, and returns a status code. Its first result is the status code (a boolean), which is true if the call succeeds without errors. In this case, xpcall also returns all results from the call, after this first result. In case of any error, xpcall returns false plus the result from err.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: Coroutine module
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 Lua supports coroutines, also called collaborative multithreading. A coroutine in Lua represents an independent thread of execution. Unlike threads in multithread systems, however, a coroutine only suspends its execution by explicitly calling a yield function.\par \par You create a coroutine with a call to coroutine.create. Its sole argument is a function that is the main function of the coroutine. The create function only creates a new coroutine and returns a handle to it (an object of type thread); it does not start the coroutine execution.\par \par When you first call coroutine.resume, passing as its first argument a thread returned by coroutine.create, the coroutine starts its execution, at the first line of its main function. Extra arguments passed to coroutine.resume are passed on to the coroutine main function. After the coroutine starts running, it runs until it terminates or yields.\par \par A coroutine can terminate its execution in two ways: normally, when its main function returns (explicitly or implicitly, after the last instruction); and abnormally, if there is an unprotected error. In the first case, coroutine.resume returns true, plus any values returned by the coroutine main function. In case of errors, coroutine.resume returns false plus an error message.\par \par A coroutine yields by calling coroutine.yield. When a coroutine yields, the corresponding coroutine.resume returns immediately, even if the yield happens inside nested function calls (that is, not in the main function, but in a function directly or indirectly called by the main function). In the case of a yield, coroutine.resume also returns true, plus any values passed to coroutine.yield. The next time you resume the same coroutine, it continues its execution from the point where it yielded, with the call to coroutine.yield returning any extra arguments passed to coroutine.resume.\par \par Like coroutine.create, the coroutine.wrap function also creates a coroutine, but instead of returning the coroutine itself, it returns a function that, when called, resumes the coroutine. Any arguments passed to this function go as extra arguments to coroutine.resume. coroutine.wrap returns all the values returned by coroutine.resume, except the first one (the boolean error code). Unlike coroutine.resume, coroutine.wrap does not catch errors; any error is propagated to the caller.\par }
HelpDataItem.example:
function foo (a) print("foo", a) return coroutine.yield(2*a) end
co = coroutine.create(function (a,b) print("co-body", a, b) local r = foo(a+1) print("co-body", r) local r, s = coroutine.yield(a+b, a-b) print("co-body", r, s) return b, "end" end)
print("main", coroutine.resume(co, 1, 10)) print("main", coroutine.resume(co, "r")) print("main", coroutine.resume(co, "x", "y")) print("main", coroutine.resume(co, "x", "y"))

HelpDataItem.name: coroutine.create (f)
coroutine.resume (co [, val1, ···])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 coroutine.resume (co [, val1, \'b7\'b7\'b7])\par \par Starts or continues the execution of coroutine co. The first time you resume a coroutine, it starts running its body. The values val1, \'b7\'b7\'b7 are passed as the arguments to the body function. If the coroutine has yielded, resume restarts it; the values val1, \'b7\'b7\'b7 are passed as the results from the yield.\par \par If the coroutine runs without any errors, resume returns true plus any values passed to yield (if the coroutine yields) or any values returned by the body function (if the coroutine terminates). If there is any error, resume returns false plus the error message.\par }

Debug module
debug.debug ()
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 debug.debug ()\par \par Enters an interactive mode with the user, running each string that the user enters. Using simple commands and other debug facilities, the user can inspect global and local variables, change their values, evaluate expressions, and so on. A line containing only the word cont finishes this function, so that the caller continues its execution.\par \par Note that commands for debug.debug are not lexically nested within any function, and so have no direct access to local variables.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: debug.getfenv (o)
debug.gethook ([thread])
debug.getinfo ([thread,] function [, what])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 debug.getinfo ([thread,] function [, what])\par \par Returns a table with information about a function. You can give the function directly, or you can give a number as the value of function, which means the function running at level function of the call stack of the given thread: level 0 is the current function (getinfo itself); level 1 is the function that called getinfo; and so on. If function is a number larger than the number of active functions, then getinfo returns nil.\par \par The returned table can contain all the fields returned by lua_getinfo, with the string what describing which fields to fill in. The default for what is to get all information available, except the table of valid lines. If present, the option 'f' adds a field named func with the function itself. If present, the option 'L' adds a field named activelines with the table of valid lines.\par \par For instance, the expression debug.getinfo(1,"n").name returns a table with a name for the current function, if a reasonable name can be found, and the expression debug.getinfo(print) returns a table with all available information about the print function.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: debug.getlocal ([thread,] level, local)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 debug.getlocal ([thread,] level, local)\par \par This function returns the name and the value of the local variable with index local of the function at level level of the stack. (The first parameter or local variable has index 1, and so on, until the last active local variable.) The function returns nil if there is no local variable with the given index, and raises an error when called with a level out of range. (You can call debug.getinfo to check whether the level is valid.)\par \par Variable names starting with '(' (open parentheses) represent internal variables (loop control variables, temporaries, and C function locals).\par }

HelpDataItem.name: debug.getmetatable (object)
debug.getregistry ()
debug.getupvalue (func, up)
debug.setfenv (object, table)
debug.sethook ([thread,] hook, mask [, count])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 debug.sethook ([thread,] hook, mask [, count])\par \par Sets the given function as a hook. The string mask and the number count describe when the hook will be called. The string mask may have the following characters, with the given meaning:\par \par "c": the hook is called every time Lua calls a function;\par "r": the hook is called every time Lua returns from a function;\par "l": the hook is called every time Lua enters a new line of code.\par With a count different from zero, the hook is called after every count instructions.\par \par When called without arguments, debug.sethook turns off the hook.\par \par When the hook is called, its first parameter is a string describing the event that has triggered its call: "call", "return" (or "tail return", when simulating a return from a tail call), "line", and "count". For line events, the hook also gets the new line number as its second parameter. Inside a hook, you can call getinfo with level 2 to get more information about the running function (level 0 is the getinfo function, and level 1 is the hook function), unless the event is "tail return". In this case, Lua is only simulating the return, and a call to getinfo will return invalid data.\par }

IO module
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 The I/O library provides two different styles for file manipulation. The first one uses implicit file descriptors; that is, there are operations to set a default input file and a default output file, and all input/output operations are over these default files. The second style uses explicit file descriptors.\par \par When using implicit file descriptors, all operations are supplied by table io. When using explicit file descriptors, the operation io.open returns a file descriptor and then all operations are supplied as methods of the file descriptor.\par \par The table io also provides three predefined file descriptors with their usual meanings from C: io.stdin, io.stdout, and io.stderr. The I/O library never closes these files.\par \par Unless otherwise stated, all I/O functions return nil on failure (plus an error message as a second result and a system-dependent error code as a third result) and some value different from nil on success.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: io.stderr
io.stdin
io.stdout
io.close ([file])
io.flush ()
io.input ([file])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 io.input ([file])\par \par When called with a file name, it opens the named file (in text mode), and sets its handle as the default input file. When called with a file handle, it simply sets this file handle as the default input file. When called without parameters, it returns the current default input file.\par \par In case of errors this function raises the error, instead of returning an error code.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: io.lines ([filename])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 io.lines ([filename])\par \par Opens the given file name in read mode and returns an iterator function that, each time it is called, returns a new line from the file. Therefore, the construction\par \par for line in io.lines(filename) do body end\par will iterate over all lines of the file. When the iterator function detects the end of file, it returns nil (to finish the loop) and automatically closes the file.\par \par The call io.lines() (with no file name) is equivalent to io.input():lines(); that is, it iterates over the lines of the default input file. In this case it does not close the file when the loop ends.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: io.open (filename [, mode])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 io.open (filename [, mode])\par \par This function opens a file, in the mode specified in the string mode. It returns a new file handle, or, in case of errors, nil plus an error message.\par \par The mode string can be any of the following:\par \par "r": read mode (the default);\par "w": write mode;\par "a": append mode;\par "r+": update mode, all previous data is preserved;\par "w+": update mode, all previous data is erased;\par "a+": append update mode, previous data is preserved, writing is only allowed at the end of file.\par The mode string can also have a 'b' at the end, which is needed in some systems to open the file in binary mode. This string is exactly what is used in the standard C function fopen.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: io.output ([file])
io.popen (prog [, mode])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 io.popen (prog [, mode])\par \par Starts program prog in a separated process and returns a file handle that you can use to read data from this program (if mode is "r", the default) or to write data to this program (if mode is "w").\par \par This function is system dependent and is not available on all platforms.\par }

Math module
math.huge
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.huge\par \par The value HUGE_VAL, a value larger than or equal to any other numerical value.\par math.huge is a constant. It represents +infinity.\par \par > = math.huge\par inf\par > = math.huge / 2\par inf\par > = -math.huge\par -inf\par > = math.huge/math.huge -- indeterminate\par nan\par > = math.huge * 0 -- indeterminate\par nan\par > = 1/0\par inf\par > = (math.huge == math.huge)\par true\par > = (1/0 == math.huge)\par true\par Note that some operations on math.huge return a special "not-a-number" value that displays as nan. This is a bit of a misnomer. nan is a number type, though it's different from other numbers:\par \par > = type(math.huge * 0)\par number\par See also FloatingPoint.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.pi
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.pi\par \par This is the constant PI.\par \par > = math.pi\par 3.1415926535898\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.acos (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.acos (x)\par \par Returns the arc cosine of x (in radians).\par \par \par }
HelpDataItem.example: Return the inverse cosine and sine of the given value. > = math.acos(1) 0 > = math.acos(0) 1.5707963267949 > = math.asin(0) 0 > = math.asin(1) 1.5707963267949

HelpDataItem.name: math.atan (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.atan (x)\par \par Returns the arc tangent of x (in radians).\par \par \par Return the inverse tangent. We can do this by supplying y/x ourselves using math.atan or we can pass y and x to math.atan2 to do this for us.\par > c, s = math.cos(0.8), math.sin(0.8)\par > = math.atan(s/c)\par 0.8\par > = math.atan2(s,c)\par 0.8\par math.atan2 should usually be preferred, particularly when converting rectangular co-ordinates to polar co-ordinates. math.atan2 uses the sign of both arguments to place the result into the correct quadrant, and also produces correct values when one of its arguments is 0 or very close to 0.\par \par > = math.atan2(1, 0), math.atan2(-1, 0), math.atan2(0, 1), math.atan2(0, -1)\par 1.5707963267949 -1.5707963267949 0 3.1415926535898\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.atan2 (y, x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.atan2 (y, x)\par \par Returns the arc tangent of y/x (in radians), but uses the signs of both parameters to find the quadrant of the result. (It also handles correctly the case of x being zero.)\par \par Return the inverse tangent. We can do this by supplying y/x ourselves using math.atan or we can pass y and x to math.atan2 to do this for us.\par > c, s = math.cos(0.8), math.sin(0.8)\par > = math.atan(s/c)\par 0.8\par > = math.atan2(s,c)\par 0.8\par math.atan2 should usually be preferred, particularly when converting rectangular co-ordinates to polar co-ordinates. math.atan2 uses the sign of both arguments to place the result into the correct quadrant, and also produces correct values when one of its arguments is 0 or very close to 0.\par \par > = math.atan2(1, 0), math.atan2(-1, 0), math.atan2(0, 1), math.atan2(0, -1)\par 1.5707963267949 -1.5707963267949 0 3.1415926535898\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.ceil (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.ceil (x)\par \par Returns the smallest integer larger than or equal to x.\par \par Return the integer no greater than or no less than the given value.\par > = math.floor(0.5)\par 0\par > = math.ceil(0.5)\par 1\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.cos (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.cos (x)\par \par Returns the cosine of x (assumed to be in radians).\par \par Return the cosine, sine and tangent value for a given value in radians.\par > = math.cos(math.pi / 4)\par 0.70710678118655\par > = math.sin(0.123)\par 0.12269009002432\par > = math.tan(5/4)\par 3.0095696738628\par > = math.tan(.77)\par 0.96966832796149\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.cosh (x)
math.deg (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.deg (x)\par \par Returns the angle x (given in radians) in degrees.\par \par Convert from radians to degrees and vice versa.\par > = math.deg(math.pi)\par 180\par > = math.deg(math.pi / 2)\par 90\par > = math.rad(180)\par 3.1415926535898\par > = math.rad(1)\par 0.017453292519943\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.exp (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.exp (x)\par \par Returns the value ex.\par \par math.exp(myval) returns e (the base of natural logarithms) raised to the power myval. math.log() returns the inverse of this. math.exp(1) returns e.\par > = math.exp(0)\par 1\par > = math.exp(1)\par 2.718281828459\par > = math.exp(27)\par 532048240601.8\par > = math.log(532048240601)\par 26.999999999998\par > = math.log(3)\par 1.0986122886681\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.floor (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.floor (x)\par \par Returns the largest integer smaller than or equal to x.\par \par Return the integer no greater than or no less than the given value.\par > = math.floor(0.5)\par 0\par > = math.ceil(0.5)\par 1\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.fmod (x, y)
math.frexp (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.frexp (x)\par \par Returns m and e such that x = m2e, e is an integer and the absolute value of m is in the range [0.5, 1) (or zero when x is zero).\par These are normalisation functions [6]. The math.frexp() function is used to split the number value into a normalized fraction and an exponent. Two values are returned: the first is a value always in the range 1/2 (inclusive) to 1 (exclusive) and the second is an exponent. The math.ldexp() function takes a normalised number and returns the floating point representation. This is the value multiplied by 2 to the power of the exponent.\par > = math.frexp(2)\par 0.5 2\par > = math.frexp(3)\par 0.75 2\par > = math.frexp(128)\par 0.5 8\par > = math.frexp(3.1415927)\par 0.785398175 2\par > = math.ldexp(0.785,2)\par 3.14\par > = math.ldexp(0.5,8)\par 128\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.ldexp (m, e)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.ldexp (m, e)\par \par Returns m2e (e should be an integer).\par \par These are normalisation functions [6]. The math.frexp() function is used to split the number value into a normalized fraction and an exponent. Two values are returned: the first is a value always in the range 1/2 (inclusive) to 1 (exclusive) and the second is an exponent. The math.ldexp() function takes a normalised number and returns the floating point representation. This is the value multiplied by 2 to the power of the exponent.\par > = math.frexp(2)\par 0.5 2\par > = math.frexp(3)\par 0.75 2\par > = math.frexp(128)\par 0.5 8\par > = math.frexp(3.1415927)\par 0.785398175 2\par > = math.ldexp(0.785,2)\par 3.14\par > = math.ldexp(0.5,8)\par 128\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.log (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.log (x)\par \par Returns the natural logarithm of x.\par \par math.exp(myval) returns e (the base of natural logarithms) raised to the power myval. math.log() returns the inverse of this. math.exp(1) returns e.\par > = math.exp(0)\par 1\par > = math.exp(1)\par 2.718281828459\par > = math.exp(27)\par 532048240601.8\par > = math.log(532048240601)\par 26.999999999998\par > = math.log(3)\par 1.0986122886681\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.log10 (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.log10 (x)\par \par Returns the base-10 logarithm of x.\par \par Return the base 10 logarithm of a given number. The number must be positive.\par > = math.log10(100)\par 2\par > = math.log10(256)\par 2.4082399653118\par > = math.log10(-1) -- can return -1.#INF on some Windows installs\par nan\par -- I get math.log10(-1) == -1.#IND and math.log10(0) == -1.#INF (MSVC2008), as I think it should be. --DavidManura\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.max (x, ···)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.max (x, \'b7\'b7\'b7)\par \par Returns the maximum value among its arguments.\par \par Return the minimum or maximum value from a variable length list of arguments.\par > = math.min(1,2)\par 1\par > = math.min(1.2, 7, 3)\par 1.2\par > = math.min(1.2, -7, 3)\par -7\par > = math.max(1.2, -7, 3)\par 3\par > = math.max(1.2, 7, 3)\par 7\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.min (x, ···)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.min (x, \'b7\'b7\'b7)\par \par Returns the minimum value among its arguments.\par \par Return the minimum or maximum value from a variable length list of arguments.\par > = math.min(1,2)\par 1\par > = math.min(1.2, 7, 3)\par 1.2\par > = math.min(1.2, -7, 3)\par -7\par > = math.max(1.2, -7, 3)\par 3\par > = math.max(1.2, 7, 3)\par 7\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.modf (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.modf (x)\par \par Returns two numbers, the integral part of x and the fractional part of x.\par \par Return the integral and fractional parts of the given number.\par > = math.modf(5)\par 5 0\par > = math.modf(5.3)\par 5 0.3\par > = math.modf(-5.3)\par -5 -0.3\par If you want the modulus (remainder), look for the modulo % operator instead.[3]\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.pow (x, y)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.pow (x, y)\par \par Returns xy. (You can also use the expression x^y to compute this value.)\par \par math.pow() raises the first parameter to the power of the second parameter and returns the result. The binary ^ operator performs the same job as math.pow(), i.e. math.pow(x,y) == x^y.\par > = math.pow(100,0)\par 1\par > = math.pow(7,2)\par 49\par > = math.pow(2,8)\par 256\par > = math.pow(3,2.7)\par 19.419023519771\par > = 5 ^ 2\par 25\par > = 2^8\par 256\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.rad (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.rad (x)\par \par Returns the angle x (given in degrees) in radians.\par \par Convert from radians to degrees and vice versa.\par > = math.deg(math.pi)\par 180\par > = math.deg(math.pi / 2)\par 90\par > = math.rad(180)\par 3.1415926535898\par > = math.rad(1)\par 0.017453292519943\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.random ([m [, n]])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.random ([m [, n]])\par \par This function is an interface to the simple pseudo-random generator function rand provided by ANSI C. (No guarantees can be given for its statistical properties.)\par \par When called without arguments, returns a uniform pseudo-random real number in the range [0,1). When called with an integer number m, math.random returns a uniform pseudo-random integer in the range [1, m]. When called with two integer numbers m and n, math.random returns a uniform pseudo-random integer in the range [m, n].\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.randomseed (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.randomseed (x)\par \par Sets x as the "seed" for the pseudo-random generator: equal seeds produce equal sequences of numbers.\par \par \par math.random() generates pseudo-random numbers uniformly distributed. Supplying argument alters its behaviour:\par math.random() with no arguments generates a real number between 0 and 1.\par math.random(upper) generates integer numbers between 1 and upper.\par math.random(lower, upper) generates integer numbers between lower and upper.\par > = math.random()\par 0.0012512588885159\par > = math.random()\par 0.56358531449324\par > = math.random(100)\par 20\par > = math.random(100)\par 81\par > = math.random(70,80)\par 76\par > = math.random(70,80)\par 75\par upper and lower must be integer. In other case Lua casts upper into an integer, sometimes giving math.floor(upper) and others math.ceil(upper), with unexpected results (the same for lower).\par The math.randomseed() function sets a seed for the pseudo-random generator: Equal seeds produce equal sequences of numbers.\par \par > math.randomseed(1234)\par > = math.random(), math.random(), math.random()\par 0.12414929654836 0.0065004425183874 0.3894466994232\par > math.randomseed(1234)\par > = math.random(), math.random(), math.random()\par 0.12414929654836 0.0065004425183874 0.3894466994232\par A good* 'seed' is os.time(), but wait a second before calling the function to obtain another sequence! To get nice random numbers use:\par \par math.randomseed( os.time() )\par If Lua could get milliseconds from os.time() the init could be better done.\par Nevertheless, in some cases we need a controlled sequence, like the obtained with a known seed.\par \par But beware! The first random number you get is not really 'randomized' (at least in Windows 2K and OS X). To get better pseudo-random number just pop some random number before using them for real:\par \par -- Initialize the pseudo random number generator\par math.randomseed( os.time() )\par math.random(); math.random(); math.random()\par -- done. :-)\par -- This not exactly true. The first random number is as good (or bad) as the second one and the others. The goodness of the generator depends on other things. To improve somewhat the built-in generator we can use a table in the form:\par \par -- improving the built-in pseudorandom generator\par do\par local oldrandom = math.random\par local randomtable\par math.random = function ()\par if randomtable == nil then\par randomtable = \{\}\par for i = 1, 97 do\par randomtable[i] = oldrandom()\par end\par end\par local x = oldrandom()\par local i = 1 + math.floor(97*x)\par x, randomtable[i] = randomtable[i], x\par return x\par end\par end\par [4] : Why math.random() might give weird results on OSX and FreeBSD?\par \par *...The problem seems to be that when the seeds differ very little the first value of generated by BSD rand() also differ very little. This difference is lost when Lua converts the integer returned by rand() into a real number, effectively preserving only the high bits in the result. When you call math.random(1,100) from Lua, the low-bit difference vanishes and you see the same integer result.\par \par -- improve seeding on these platforms by throwing away the high part of time, \par -- then reversing the digits so the least significant part makes the biggest change\par -- NOTE this should not be considered a replacement for using a stronger random function\par -- ~ferrix\par math.randomseed( tonumber(tostring(os.time()):reverse():sub(1,6)) )\par There is also lrandom[5] A library for generating random numbers based on the Mersenne Twister.\par }

HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.sin (x)\par \par Returns the sine of x (assumed to be in radians).\par Return the cosine, sine and tangent value for a given value in radians.\par > = math.cos(math.pi / 4)\par 0.70710678118655\par > = math.sin(0.123)\par 0.12269009002432\par > = math.tan(5/4)\par 3.0095696738628\par > = math.tan(.77)\par 0.96966832796149\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.sinh (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.sinh (x)\par \par Returns the hyperbolic sine of x.\par \par Return the hyperbolic cosine, hyperbolic sine, and hyperbolic tangent[2] value for a given value.\par > = math.sinh(1)\par 1.1752011936438\par }

HelpDataItem.name: math.sqrt (x)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.sqrt (x)\par \par Returns the square root of x. (You can also use the expression x^0.5 to compute this value.)\par \par \par Return the square root of a given number. Only non-negative arguments are allowed.\par > = math.sqrt(100)\par 10\par > = math.sqrt(1234)\par 35.128336140501\par > = math.sqrt(-7)\par -1.#IND\par }

HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 math.tan (x)\par \par Returns the tangent of x (assumed to be in radians).\par Return the cosine, sine and tangent value for a given value in radians.\par > = math.cos(math.pi / 4)\par 0.70710678118655\par > = math.sin(0.123)\par 0.12269009002432\par > = math.tan(5/4)\par 3.0095696738628\par > = math.tan(.77)\par 0.96966832796149\par }

OS module
os.clock ()
os.date ([format [, time]])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 os.date ([format [, time]])\par \par Returns a string or a table containing date and time, formatted according to the given string format.\par \par If the time argument is present, this is the time to be formatted (see the os.time function for a description of this value). Otherwise, date formats the current time.\par \par If format starts with '!', then the date is formatted in Coordinated Universal Time. After this optional character, if format is the string "*t", then date returns a table with the following fields: year (four digits), month (1--12), day (1--31), hour (0--23), min (0--59), sec (0--61), wday (weekday, Sunday is 1), yday (day of the year), and isdst (daylight saving flag, a boolean).\par \par If format is not "*t", then date returns the date as a string, formatted according to the same rules as the C function strftime.\par \par When called without arguments, date returns a reasonable date and time representation that depends on the host system and on the current locale (that is, os.date() is equivalent to os.date("%c")).\par }

HelpDataItem.name: os.difftime (t2, t1)
os.execute ([command])
os.exit ([code])
os.getenv (varname)

os.setlocale (locale [, category])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 os.setlocale (locale [, category])\par \par Sets the current locale of the program. locale is a string specifying a locale; category is an optional string describing which category to change: "all", "collate", "ctype", "monetary", "numeric", or "time"; the default category is "all". The function returns the name of the new locale, or nil if the request cannot be honored.\par \par If locale is the empty string, the current locale is set to an implementation-defined native locale. If locale is the string "C", the current locale is set to the standard C locale.\par \par When called with nil as the first argument, this function only returns the name of the current locale for the given category.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: os.time ([table])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 os.time ([table])\par \par Returns the current time when called without arguments, or a time representing the date and time specified by the given table. This table must have fields year, month, and day, and may have fields hour, min, sec, and isdst (for a description of these fields, see the os.date function).\par \par The returned value is a number, whose meaning depends on your system. In POSIX, Windows, and some other systems, this number counts the number of seconds since some given start time (the "epoch"). In other systems, the meaning is not specified, and the number returned by time can be used only as an argument to date and difftime.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: os.tmpname ()
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 os.tmpname ()\par \par Returns a string with a file name that can be used for a temporary file. The file must be explicitly opened before its use and explicitly removed when no longer needed.\par \par On some systems (POSIX), this function also creates a file with that name, to avoid security risks. (Someone else might create the file with wrong permissions in the time between getting the name and creating the file.) You still have to open the file to use it and to remove it (even if you do not use it).\par \par When possible, you may prefer to use io.tmpfile, which automatically removes the file when the program ends.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: Package module
package.cpath
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 package.cpath\par \par The path used by require to search for a C loader.\par \par Lua initializes the C path package.cpath in the same way it initializes the Lua path package.path, using the environment variable LUA_CPATH or a default path defined in luaconf.h.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: package.loaded
package.loaders
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 package.loaders\par \par A table used by require to control how to load modules.\par \par Each entry in this table is a searcher function. When looking for a module, require calls each of these searchers in ascending order, with the module name (the argument given to require) as its sole parameter. The function can return another function (the module loader) or a string explaining why it did not find that module (or nil if it has nothing to say). Lua initializes this table with four functions.\par \par The first searcher simply looks for a loader in the package.preload table.\par \par The second searcher looks for a loader as a Lua library, using the path stored at package.path. A path is a sequence of templates separated by semicolons. For each template, the searcher will change each interrogation mark in the template by filename, which is the module name with each dot replaced by a "directory separator" (such as "/" in Unix); then it will try to open the resulting file name. So, for instance, if the Lua path is the string\par \par "./?.lua;./?.lc;/usr/local/?/init.lua"\par the search for a Lua file for module foo will try to open the files ./foo.lua, ./foo.lc, and /usr/local/foo/init.lua, in that order.\par \par The third searcher looks for a loader as a C library, using the path given by the variable package.cpath. For instance, if the C path is the string\par \par "./?.so;./?.dll;/usr/local/?/init.so"\par the searcher for module foo will try to open the files ./foo.so, ./foo.dll, and /usr/local/foo/init.so, in that order. Once it finds a C library, this searcher first uses a dynamic link facility to link the application with the library. Then it tries to find a C function inside the library to be used as the loader. The name of this C function is the string "luaopen_" concatenated with a copy of the module name where each dot is replaced by an underscore. Moreover, if the module name has a hyphen, its prefix up to (and including) the first hyphen is removed. For instance, if the module name is a.v1-b.c, the function name will be luaopen_b_c.\par \par The fourth searcher tries an all-in-one loader. It searches the C path for a library for the root name of the given module. For instance, when requiring a.b.c, it will search for a C library for a. If found, it looks into it for an open function for the submodule; in our example, that would be luaopen_a_b_c. With this facility, a package can pack several C submodules into one single library, with each submodule keeping its original open function.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: package.loadlib (libname, funcname)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 package.loadlib (libname, funcname)\par \par Dynamically links the host program with the C library libname. Inside this library, looks for a function funcname and returns this function as a C function. (So, funcname must follow the protocol (see lua_CFunction)).\par \par This is a low-level function. It completely bypasses the package and module system. Unlike require, it does not perform any path searching and does not automatically adds extensions. libname must be the complete file name of the C library, including if necessary a path and extension. funcname must be the exact name exported by the C library (which may depend on the C compiler and linker used).\par \par This function is not supported by ANSI C. As such, it is only available on some platforms (Windows, Linux, Mac OS X, Solaris, BSD, plus other Unix systems that support the dlfcn standard).\par }

HelpDataItem.name: package.path
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 package.path\par \par The path used by require to search for a Lua loader.\par \par At start-up, Lua initializes this variable with the value of the environment variable LUA_PATH or with a default path defined in luaconf.h, if the environment variable is not defined. Any ";;" in the value of the environment variable is replaced by the default path.\par }

String module
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 This library provides generic functions for string manipulation, such as finding and extracting substrings, and pattern matching. When indexing a string in Lua, the first character is at position 1 (not at 0, as in C). Indices are allowed to be negative and are interpreted as indexing backwards, from the end of the string. Thus, the last character is at position -1, and so on.\par \par The string library provides all its functions inside the table string. It also sets a metatable for strings where the __index field points to the string table. Therefore, you can use the string functions in object-oriented style. For instance, string.byte(s, i) can be written as s:byte(i).\par \par The string library assumes one-byte character encodings.\par \par }

HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 string.char (\'b7\'b7\'b7)\par \par Receives zero or more integers. Returns a string with length equal to the number of arguments, in which each character has the internal numerical code equal to its corresponding argument.\par Note that numerical codes are not necessarily portable across platforms.\par \par }

HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 string.format (formatstring, \'b7\'b7\'b7)\par \par Returns a formatted version of its variable number of arguments following the description given in its first argument (which must be a string). The format string follows the same rules as the printf family of standard C functions. The only differences are that the options/modifiers *, l, L, n, p, and h are not supported and that there is an extra option, q. The q option formats a string in a form suitable to be safely read back by the Lua interpreter: the string is written between double quotes, and all double quotes, newlines, embedded zeros, and backslashes in the string are correctly escaped when written. For instance, the call\par string.format('%q', 'a string with "quotes" and \\n new line')\par will produce the string:\par \par "a string with \\"quotes\\" and \\\par new line"\par The options c, d, E, e, f, g, G, i, o, u, X, and x all expect a number as argument, whereas q and s expect a string.\par \par This function does not accept string values containing embedded zeros, except as arguments to the q option.\par }
HelpDataItem.example: string.format('%q', 'a string with "quotes" and \n new line')

HelpDataItem.name: string.gmatch (s, pattern)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 string.gmatch (s, pattern)\par \par Returns an iterator function that, each time it is called, returns the next captures from pattern over string s. If pattern specifies no captures, then the whole match is produced in each call.\par As an example, the following loop\par \par s = "hello world from Lua"\par for w in string.gmatch(s, "%a+") do\par print(w)\par end\par will iterate over all the words from string s, printing one per line. The next example collects all pairs key=value from the given string into a table:\par \par t = \{\}\par s = "from=world, to=Lua"\par for k, v in string.gmatch(s, "(%w+)=(%w+)") do\par t[k] = v\par end\par For this function, a '^' at the start of a pattern does not work as an anchor, as this would prevent the iteration.\par }
HelpDataItem.example: s = "hello world from Lua" for w in string.gmatch(s, "%a+") do print(w) end

HelpDataItem.name: string.gsub (s, pattern, repl [, n])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 string.gsub (s, pattern, repl [, n])\par \par Returns a copy of s in which all (or the first n, if given) occurrences of the pattern have been replaced by a replacement string specified by repl, which can be a string, a table, or a function. gsub also returns, as its second value, the total number of matches that occurred.\par If repl is a string, then its value is used for replacement. The character % works as an escape character: any sequence in repl of the form %n, with n between 1 and 9, stands for the value of the n-th captured substring (see below). The sequence %0 stands for the whole match. The sequence %% stands for a single %.\par \par If repl is a table, then the table is queried for every match, using the first capture as the key; if the pattern specifies no captures, then the whole match is used as the key.\par \par If repl is a function, then this function is called every time a match occurs, with all captured substrings passed as arguments, in order; if the pattern specifies no captures, then the whole match is passed as a sole argument.\par \par If the value returned by the table query or by the function call is a string or a number, then it is used as the replacement string; otherwise, if it is false or nil, then there is no replacement (that is, the original match is kept in the string).\par \par Here are some examples:\par \par x = string.gsub("hello world", "(%w+)", "%1 %1")\par --> x="hello hello world world"\par \par x = string.gsub("hello world", "%w+", "%0 %0", 1)\par --> x="hello hello world"\par \par x = string.gsub("hello world from Lua", "(%w+)%s*(%w+)", "%2 %1")\par --> x="world hello Lua from"\par \par x = string.gsub("home = $HOME, user = $USER", "%$(%w+)", os.getenv)\par --> x="home = /home/roberto, user = roberto"\par \par x = string.gsub("4+5 = $return 4+5$", "%$(.-)%$", function (s)\par return loadstring(s)()\par end)\par --> x="4+5 = 9"\par \par local t = \{name="lua", version="5.1"\}\par x = string.gsub("$name-$version.tar.gz", "%$(%w+)", t)\par --> x="lua-5.1.tar.gz"\par }

File class
HelpDataItem.example:
-- Find the length of a file -- filename: file name -- returns -- len: length of file -- asserts on error function length_of_file(filename) local fh = assert(io.open(filename, "rb")) local len = assert(fh:seek("end")) fh:close() return len end
-- Return true if file exists and is readable. function file_exists(path) local file = io.open(path, "rb") if file then file:close() end return file ~= nil end
-- Guarded seek. -- Same as file:seek except throws string -- on error. -- Requires Lua 5.1. function seek(fh, ...) assert(fh:seek(...)) end

HelpDataItem.name: file:close ()
file:flush ()
file:lines ()
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 file:lines ()\par \par Returns an iterator function that, each time it is called, returns a new line from the file. Therefore, the construction\par \par for line in file:lines() do body end\par will iterate over all lines of the file. (Unlike io.lines, this function does not close the file when the loop ends.)\par }

HelpDataItem.name: file:read (···)
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 file:read (\'b7\'b7\'b7)\par \par Reads the file file, according to the given formats, which specify what to read. For each format, the function returns a string (or a number) with the characters read, or nil if it cannot read data with the specified format. When called without formats, it uses a default format that reads the entire next line (see below).\par \par The available formats are\par \par "*n": reads a number; this is the only format that returns a number instead of a string.\par "*a": reads the whole file, starting at the current position. On end of file, it returns the empty string.\par "*l": reads the next line (skipping the end of line), returning nil on end of file. This is the default format.\par number: reads a string with up to this number of characters, returning nil on end of file. If number is zero, it reads nothing and returns an empty string, or nil on end of file.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: file:seek ([whence] [, offset])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 file:seek ([whence] [, offset])\par \par Sets and gets the file position, measured from the beginning of the file, to the position given by offset plus a base specified by the string whence, as follows:\par \par "set": base is position 0 (beginning of the file);\par "cur": base is current position;\par "end": base is end of file;\par In case of success, function seek returns the final file position, measured in bytes from the beginning of the file. If this function fails, it returns nil, plus a string describing the error.\par \par The default value for whence is "cur", and for offset is 0. Therefore, the call file:seek() returns the current file position, without changing it; the call file:seek("set") sets the position to the beginning of the file (and returns 0); and the call file:seek("end") sets the position to the end of the file, and returns its size.\par }

HelpDataItem.name: file:setvbuf (mode [, size])
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1250\deff0\deflang1045{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset238 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 file:setvbuf (mode [, size])\par \par Sets the buffering mode for an output file. There are three available modes:\par \par "no": no buffering; the result of any output operation appears immediately.\par "full": full buffering; output operation is performed only when the buffer is full (or when you explicitly flush the file (see io.flush)).\par "line": line buffering; output is buffered until a newline is output or there is any input from some special files (such as a terminal device).\par For the last two cases, size specifies the size of the buffer, in bytes. The default is an appropriate size.\par }

Base Game Actions
AcceptPartyInvite (accept:bool) : bool
Action (actionId, withShift, withCtrl) : bool
HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 Function allow to run some actions.\par \par withShift, withCtrl = TRUE/FALSE\par \par \par Action List [from H5] [ID,Name,Desc] \par 0 = Sit/Stand = Toggle Sit/Stand. (/sit, /stand)\par 1 = Walk/Run = Toggle Walk/Run. (/walk, /run)\par 2 = Attack = Attacks selected target(s), or takes a general action if the target cannot be attacked. Hold down the Ctrl key and click to attack by force. \par 3 = Exchange = Request a trade from the selected target. (/trade)\par 4 = Next Target = Select the nearest attackable target. (/targetnext)\par 5 = Pick Up = Pick up items that are scattered nearby. (/pickup)\par 6 = Assist = Change to the target of the currently selected player. (/assist)\par 7 = Invite = Invite the selected person to your party. (/invite)\par 8 = Leave Party = Leave the party. (/leave)\par 9 = Dismiss Party Member = If you are the leader of the party, dismiss selected members from your party. (/dismiss)\par 10 = Private Store - Sell = Sets up a private store to sell your items. (/vendor)\par 11 = Party Matching = Display the party matching window to search for parties or to add members to your party. (/partymatching)\par 12 = Greeting = Emote: Greet others with a kind "hello." (/socialhello)\par 13 = Victory = Emote: Let everyone know that you or someone else is victorious! (/socialvictory)\par 14 = Advance = Emote: Rouse your allies and charge! (/socialcharge)\par 15 = Change Movement Mode = Have your pet follow you or stay and hold its ground.\par 16 = Attack = Attack target.\par 17 = Stop = Stop current action.\par 18 = Pickup = Pick up nearby items.\par 19 = Unsummon Pet = Returns your pet back to its home.\par 20 = Special skill = Use special skill.\par 21 = Change Movement Mode = Have your summons follow you or stay and hold its ground.\par 22 = Attack = Attack target.\par 23 = Stop = Stop current action.\par 24 = Yes = Emote: Respond positively. (/socialyes)\par 25 = No = Emote: Respond negatively. (/socialno)\par 26 = Bow = Emote: Show your respect and bow. (/socialbow)\par 27 = Special skill = Use special skill.\par 28 = Private Store - Buy = Sets up a private store to purchase items. (/buy)\par 29 = Unaware = Emote: You have no idea what's going on. (/socialunaware)\par 30 = Social Waiting = Emote: I'm waiting... (/socialwaiting)\par 31 = Laugh = Emote: Have a good laugh. (/sociallaugh)\par 32 = Switch Mode = Toggle between Attack/Move modes.\par 33 = Applaud = Emote: Applaud. (/socialapplause)\par 34 = Dance = Emote: Serve them up your best dance moves. (/socialdance)\par 35 = Sorrow = Emote: Show grief. (/socialsad)\par 36 = Toxic Smoke = Poison gas attack.\par 37 = Dwarven Manufacture = Set up a private crafting store that creates items by using Dwarven recipes in exchange for a fee. (/dwarvenmanufacture)\par 38 = Mount/Dismount = Toggle mount/dismount when near or on an NPC that can be ridden. (/mount, /dismount, /mountdismount)\par 39 = Parasite Burst = Exploding corpse attack.\par 40 = Recommend = Enhances a target's evaluation score. (/evaluate)\par 41 = Wild Cannon = Attacks castle gates, walls, or headquarters by shooting a cannon.\par 42 = Self Damage Shield = Reflects damage back to an enemy.\par 43 = Hydro Screw = Attacks an enemy by creating a whirling surge of water.\par 44 = Boom Attack = Attacks an enemy with a powerful explosion.\par 45 = Master Recharge = Restores the summoner's MP.\par 46 = Mega Storm Strike = Attacks an enemy by summoning up a devastating storm.\par 47 = Steal Blood = Damages an enemy and heals the servitor at the same time.\par 48 = Mech. Cannon = Attacks the enemy by shooting a cannon.\par 49 = Wild Temper = Attack with a fit of rage.\par 50 = Change of Party Leader = The selected party member will become the new party leader. (/changepartyleader)\par 51 = General Manufacture = Creates an item using a common recipe in exchange for a fee.\par 52 = Unsummon = Removes the bonds from the summons and releases it.\par 53 = Move = Move to the target.\par 54 = Move = Move to the target.\par 55 = Start/End Recording Replay = Toggle recording and stop recording of replay files. \par 56 = Command Channel Invitation = Invite the selected target to a command channel. (/channelinvite)\par 57 = Find Store = Highlights private store and private crafting store messages that contain the search word. (/findprivatestore)\par 58 = Duel = Challenge another player to a duel. (/duel)\par 59 = Withdraw = Withdraw from a duel. A withdrawal is treated as a defeat. (/withdraw)\par 60 = Party Duel = Challenge another party to a duel. (/partyduel)\par 61 = Package Sale = Open a personal store for package sale. (/packagesale)\par 62 = Charm = Charm Pose\par 63 = Mini-Game = Begins a fun and easy mini-game. (command: /minigame)\par 64 = My Teleports = Displays My Teleports window you can use to save and manage my teleport locations (command: /myteleport).\par 65 = Bot Report Button = Reports the targeted player as a suspected bot.\par 66 = Shyness = Allows character to strike shy pose.\par 67 = Steer = Allows you to control the Airship.\par 68 = Cancel Control = Relinquishes control of the Airship.\par 69 = Destination Map = Choose from pre-designated locations.\par 70 = Exit Airship = Disembarks from the Airship.\par 71 = Exchange Bows = Exchange bows with another person.\par 72 = High Five = High Five another person.\par 73 = Couple Dance = Dance with another player.\par 1000 = Siege Hammer = Attacks castle gates, walls, or headquarters with a powerful strike.\par 1001 = Ultimate Bombastic Buster = A reckless yet powerful attack that must be used with extreme caution.\par 1002 = Hostile Feeling = Incites those around the summon to attack you.\par 1003 = Wild Stun = A surprise attack that inflicts damage and stuns the opponent.\par 1004 = Wild Defense = Instantly increases P. Def and M. Def significantly. Character is immovable while this skill is in effect.\par 1005 = Bright Burst = A magical attack.\par 1006 = Bright Heal = Recovers the pet's HP.\par 1007 = Blessing of Queen = Temporarily increases your party's chance to land a critical attack and also increases the power of the attack if successful.\par 1008 = Gift of Queen = Temporarily increases your party's P. Atk and accuracy.\par 1009 = Cure of Queen = Has a chance to remove curses from party members.\par 1010 = Blessing of Seraphim = Temporarily increases your party's MP regeneration.\par 1011 = Gift of Seraphim = Temporarily shortens your party's spell re-use timer.\par 1012 = Cure of Seraphim = Remove a curse from your party.\par 1013 = Curse of Shade = Provokes an opponent to attack and strikes them with a curse that decreases their P. Def and M. Def.\par 1014 = Mass Curse of Shade = Provokes multiple enemies around the caster to attack and strikes them with a curse that decreases their P. Def and M. Def.\par 1015 = Shade Sacrifice = Sacrifice HP in order to regenerate the HP of a selected target.\par 1016 = Cursed Blow = Attempt a powerful, critical attack on an opponent.\par 1017 = Cursed Stun = A stunning blow that inflicts damage and instantly throws an enemy into a state of shock.\par 1018 = Cursed Drain Energy = Inflict a deadly curse on an enemy that absorbs their HP.\par 1019 = Kat the Cat Skill 2 = Skill #2 that is used by Kat the Cat\par 1020 = Mew the Cat Skill 2 = Skill #2 that is used by Mew the Cat\par 1021 = Kai the Cat Skill 2 = Skill #2 that is used by Kai the Cat\par 1022 = Boxer the Unicorn Skill 2 = Skill #2 that is used by Boxer the Unicorn\par 1023 = Mirage the Unicorn Skill 2 = Skill #2 that is used by Mirage the Unicorn\par 1024 = Merrow the Unicorn Skill 2 = Skill #2 that is used by Merrow the Unicorn\par 1025 = Shadow Skill 1 = Skill #2 that is used by Shadow\par 1026 = Shadow Skill 2 = Skill #1 that is used by Shadow\par 1027 = Silhouette Skill 2 = Skill #2 that is used by Silhouette\par 1028 = Reanimated Man Skill 1 = Skill #1 that is used by reanimated man\par 1029 = Reanimated Man Skill 2 = Skill #2 that is used by reanimated man\par 1030 = Corrupted Man Skill 2 = Skill #2 that is used by corrupted man\par 1031 = Slash = Feline King: A powerful slashing attack. Over-hit is possible.\par 1032 = Spinning Slash = Feline King: Slashes at surrounding enemies while spinning in the air. Over-hit is possible.\par 1033 = Grip of the Cat = Feline King: Immobilizes all nearby enemies.\par 1034 = Whiplash = Magnus the Unicorn: Powerful rear kicks that stun and damage an enemy. Over-hit is possible.\par 1035 = Tidal Wave = Magnus the Unicorn: Pounds multiple enemies with a tremendous onrush of water.\par 1036 = Corpse Kaboom = Spectral Lord: Detonates a corpse, inflicting damage to nearby enemies.\par 1037 = Dicing Death = Spectral Lord: Blades attached to each arm slash out in a devastating attack. Over-hit is possible.\par 1038 = Dark Curse = Spectral Lord: Curses nearby enemies, poisoning them and reducing their Atk. Spd.\par 1039 = Cannon Fodder = Swoop Cannon: Fires a projectile a short distance. Consumes 4 Flash Gunpowder.\par 1040 = Big Bang = Swoop Cannon: Fires a projectile a long distance. Consumes 5 Flash Gunpowder.\par 1041 = Bite Attack = Viciously bite an enemy.\par 1042 = Mawl = Scratch an enemy with both paws. Causes bleeding.\par 1043 = Cry of the Wolf = Dominate nearby enemies with a mighty roar.\par 1044 = Awakening = Awaken hidden powers.\par 1045 = Wolf Howl = Decrease a nearby enemy's P. Atk./M. Atk. with a wolf cry.\par 1046 = Strider Roar = Decrease a nearby enemy's attack speed/magic speed with a strider roar.\par 1047 = Divine Beast Bite = Viciously bite an enemy.\par 1048 = Divine Beast Stun Attack = Cause both damage and shock at the same time. Instantly stuns an enemy.\par 1049 = Divine Beast Fire Breath = Breath fire in front of you.\par 1050 = Divine Beast Roar = Dominate nearby enemies with a mighty roar.\par 1051 = Bless the Body = Increases maximum HP temporarily.\par 1052 = Bless the Soul = Increases maximum MP temporarily.\par 1053 = Haste = Increases Atk. Spd. temporarily.\par 1054 = Acumen = Increases Casting Spd. temporarily.\par 1055 = Clarity = Temporarily decreases the target's MP consumption of skills. Consumes Spirit Ore.\par 1056 = Empower = Increases M. Atk. power temporarily.\par 1057 = Wild Magic = Temporarily increases the critical rate of damage attack magic.\par 1058 = Death Whisper = Temporarily increases the critical attack power.\par 1059 = Focus = Temporarily increases the probability of critical attack.\par 1060 = Guidance = Temporarily increases Accuracy.\par 1061 = Death Blow = Awakens a hidden ability to inflict a powerful attack on the enemy. Requires application of the Awakening skill.\par 1062 = Double Attack = Rapidly attacks the enemy twice.\par 1063 = Spin Attack = Inflicts shock and damage to the enemy at the same time with a powerful spin attack.\par 1064 = Meteor Shower = Attacks nearby enemies with a doll heap attack.\par 1065 = Awakening = Awakens a hidden ability.\par 1066 = Thunder Bolt = Attacks the enemy with the power of thunder.\par 1067 = Flash = Inflicts a swift magic attack on nearby enemies when hit.\par 1068 = Lightning Wave = Attacks nearby enemies with the power of lightning.\par 1069 = Flare = Awakens a hidden ability to inflict a powerful attack on the enemy. Requires application of the Awakening skill.\par 1070 = Buff Control = Control put in place to prevent the use of a buff upon the master. 5-minute duration.\par 1071 = Power Striker = Powerfully attacks the target.\par 1072 = Piercing Attack = A powerful attack that pierces through a target.\par 1073 = Whirlwind = Attacks nearby enemies by spinning your own body like a whirlwind.\par 1074 = Lance Smash = Attacks a front-line enemy with a powerful lance thrust.\par 1075 = Battle Cry = Shouts a victory cry that increases your abilities.\par 1076 = Power Smash = Inflicts a powerful attack on the target.\par 1077 = Energy Burst = Gathers energy into your body, then releases it in a destructive blast.\par 1078 = Shock Wave = Hits enemies with a powerful wave of force.\par 1079 = Howl = Emits a loud roar that amplifies your abilities.\par 1080 = Phoenix Rush = Charges toward the enemy and inflicts damage.\par 1081 = Phoenix Cleanse = Cancels the target's de-buff.\par 1082 = Phoenix Flame Feather = Emits a spread of ring-shaped flames.\par 1083 = Phoenix Flame Beak = Attacks the enemy with a powerful flaming beak.\par 1084 = Switch State = Toggles you between Attack and Support modes.\par 1086 = Panther Cancel = Cancels more than one of the enemy's buffs.\par 1087 = Panther Dark Claw = Decreases the enemy's Dark attribute by 25.\par 1088 = Panther Fatal Claw = Aims at the enemy's vital spot.\par 1089 = Tail Strike = Strike multiple enemies at the front with the tail.\par 1090 = Strider Bite = Bites the enemies at the front.\par 1091 = Strider Fear = Causes nearby enemies to flee in fear.\par 1092 = Strider Dash = Increases your speed.\par 1093 = Maguen Strike = Attacks the target with a chance to decrease target's speed.\par 1094 = Maguen Wind Walk = Greatly increases its master's speed.\par 1095 = Maguen Power Strike = Attacks the target with a chance to decrease target's speed.\par 1096 = Elite Maguen Wind Walk = Increases the speed of its master and their party.\par 1097 = Maguen Return = Teleports its master to the Seed of Annihilation.\par 1098 = Maguen Party Return = Teleports its master and their party to the Seed of Annihilation.\par 5000 = Hand of Warmth = Can express affection to Rudolph. Affection Level rises by 25%. Warning: Can be used only when a Rudolph requests expression of affection, and cannot be used while transformed!\par 5001 = Rosy Seduction = Increases Max HP by 20%, Max MP by 20%, and the Speed by 20 for 5 minutes. Increases the resistance to de-buffs by 10%. Reuse delay 10 minutes. Consumes 3 Rose Essence(s) during skill use. Doesn't overlap with other buffs except Critical Seduction.\par 5002 = Critical Seduction = For 20 minutes, increases party members' Max HP by 30%, Max MP by 30%, Max CP by 30%, P. Def. by 30%, M. Def. by 30%, Speed by 20%, P. Atk. by 10%, and M. Atk. by 20%. Decreases MP consumption for skill use by 15%. Reuse delay 40 minutes. Consumes 10 Rose Essence(s) during skill use.\par 5003 = Thunder Bolt = Attacks the enemy with the power of lightning.\par 5004 = Flash = Inflicts a swift magic attack upon contacted enemies nearby.\par 5005 = Lightning Wave = Attacks nearby enemies with the power of lightning.\par 5006 = Buff Control = Restricts to prevent the use of a buff upon the master. 5 minute duration.\par 5007 = Piercing Attack = Inflicts a powerful attack that seems to pierce through the target.\par 5008 = Spin Attack = Attacks nearby enemies.\par 5009 = Impale = Impales an enemy with a sword.\par 5010 = Battle Cry = Raises one's own abilities.\par 5011 = Power Smash = Inflicts a powerful attack on the target.\par 5012 = Energy Burst = Gathered energy within ones self can be focused and used to attack an enemy.\par 5013 = Shockwave = Fires a shock wave to attack enemies at the front.\par 5014 = Burst = Amplifies one's own abilities.\par 5015 = Switch Tactics = Switches between attack mode and support mode.\par }

HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 Enum with pickup filters:\par \par \tab // pickup exclusion filters\par \tab enum PickupDropFilters\par \tab\{\par \tab\tab PICKUP_TARGET_MOB_ME = 0x00000001, // I had mob on target when it died\par \tab\tab PICKUP_TARGET_MOB_PARTY = 0x00000002, // Someone from party had mob on target when it died\par \tab\tab PICKUP_TARGET_MOB_CLAN = 0x00000004, // Someone from clan had mob on target when it died\par \tab\tab PICKUP_TARGET_MOB_FRIEND = 0x00000008, // Someone from friend had mob on target when it died\par \tab\tab PICKUP_TARGET_MOB_OTHER = 0x00000010, // Someone else had mob on target when it died\par \par \tab\tab PICKUP_HIT_MOB_PET = 0x00002000, // My pet hit mob atlast once\par \tab\tab PICKUP_HIT_MOB_ME = 0x00000020, // I hitted mob at least once\par \tab\tab PICKUP_HIT_MOB_PARTY = 0x00000040, // Someone from party hitted mob at least once\par \tab\tab PICKUP_HIT_MOB_CLAN = 0x00000080, // Someone from clan hitted mob at least once\par \tab\tab PICKUP_HIT_MOB_FRIEND = 0x00000100, // Someone from friend hitted mob at least once\par \tab\tab PICKUP_HIT_MOB_OTHER = 0x00000200, // someone else hitted mob at least once\par \par \tab\tab PICKUP_DROP_FROM_MONSTER = 0x00000400, // monster drop\par \tab\tab PICKUP_DROP_FROM_PLAYER = 0x00000800, // player drop\par \tab\tab PICKUP_DROP_FROM_ORPHANT = 0x00001000, // all other drop\par \par \tab\tab FILTER_GROUP_TARGET = PICKUP_TARGET_MOB_ME | PICKUP_TARGET_MOB_PARTY | PICKUP_TARGET_MOB_CLAN | PICKUP_TARGET_MOB_FRIEND | PICKUP_TARGET_MOB_OTHER,\par \tab\tab FILTER_GROUP_HIT = PICKUP_HIT_MOB_PET | PICKUP_HIT_MOB_ME | PICKUP_HIT_MOB_PARTY | PICKUP_HIT_MOB_CLAN | PICKUP_HIT_MOB_FRIEND | PICKUP_HIT_MOB_OTHER,\par \tab\tab FILTER_GROUP_DROP = PICKUP_DROP_FROM_MONSTER | PICKUP_DROP_FROM_PLAYER | PICKUP_DROP_FROM_ORPHANT\par \tab\}; // enum PickupDropFilters\par }

HelpDataItem.text: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\f0\fs17 This is base class for every potions settings.\par \par Base logic for potion use looks like this:\par \par bool UsePotion ( bool isPet, unsigned __int64 & timer, const unsigned __int64 & currentTime, const L2TowerShared::PotionSetting & potion, int stat, int damage, int damagePercent, int level, ItemManager & inventory, bool useOr = false )\par \{\par \tab BEGIN_GUARD\par \tab do\par \tab\{\par \tab\tab LOG(L"UsePotion -> potionId = %d (%s)\\n", potion.ItemId, DataLayer::FL2GameData::GetSingleton()->GetItemName ( potion.ItemId ) );\par \tab\tab if ( timer >= currentTime )\par \tab\tab\{\par \tab\tab\tab LOG(L"Reuse for potion not ready");\par \tab\tab\tab break;\par \tab\tab\}\par \tab\tab if ( (!useOr) && (damage < potion.Damage) && (damagePercent < potion.DamagePercent))\par \tab\tab\{\par \tab\tab\tab LOG(L"Current damage is too low. ( damage = %d potion.Damage=%d, stat = %d, damagePercent=%d potion.DamagePercent=%d)\\n", damage, potion.Damage, stat, damagePercent, potion.DamagePercent );\par \tab\tab\tab break;\par \tab\tab\}\par \tab\tab if ( (useOr) && ((damage < potion.Damage) || (damagePercent < potion.DamagePercent)))\par \tab\tab\{\par \tab\tab\tab LOG(L"Current damage is too low. ( damage = %d potion.Damage=%d, stat = %d, damagePercent=%d potion.DamagePercent=%d)\\n", damage, potion.Damage, stat, damagePercent, potion.DamagePercent );\par \tab\tab\tab break;\par \tab\tab\}\par \tab\tab if ( potion.SkillId != L2TowerShared::Skills::None && ENGINE->GetMySkills().IsSkillAvailable(potion.SkillId) == false )\par \tab\tab\{\par \tab\tab\tab LOG(L"Skill is not available ( potion.SkillId = %d available = %d )\\n", potion.SkillId, ENGINE->GetMySkills().IsSkillAvailable(potion.SkillId) );\par \tab\tab\tab break;\par \tab\tab\}\par \tab\tab if ( level < potion.LevelMin || level > potion.LevelMax )\par \tab\tab\{\par \tab\tab\tab LOG(L"Level mismatch ( level = %d, min = %d, max = %d \\n", level, potion.LevelMin, potion.LevelMax );\par \tab\tab\tab break;\par \tab\tab\}\par \tab\tab if ( inventory.UseItem(potion.ItemId, isPet) == false )\par \tab\tab\{\par \tab\tab\tab LOG(L"Failed to use potion ( itemId = %d isPet = %d )\\n", potion.ItemId, isPet );\par \tab\tab\tab break;\par \tab\tab\} \par \tab\tab timer = currentTime + potion.CooldownTime;\par \tab\tab return true;\par \tab\} while ( 0 );\par \tab return false;\par \tab END_GUARD\par \}\par }
